content.question: The function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> shown in the figure above is continuous on the closed interval <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 12, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and differentiable on the open interval <math alttext="open parenthesis, 0 comma 12, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on the graph, what are all values of <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that satisfy the conclusion of the Mean Value Theorem applied to <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on the closed interval <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 12, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: 4.5 only because this is the value where <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> equals the average rate of change of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 12, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

3 and 8 because these are the values where <math alttext="f prime of x, equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>â€²</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> on <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 12, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

2 and 9 only because these are the values where the instantaneous rate of change of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>at those values is equal to the average rate of change of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 12, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

2, 4.5, and 9 because these are the values where either the instantaneous rate of change of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>at the value is equal to the average rate of change of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 12, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> or the value of <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is equal to the average rate of change of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 12, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: 2 and 9 only because these are the values where the instantaneous rate of change of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>at those values is equal to the average rate of change of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 12, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.
